objdescid.compdate: c. 1780-85The date is based on stylistic considerations.

objinfo.leafsize: 8.9 x 34.9 cm.The top of this strip of paper is uneven, tapering to 8.0 cm. on the right. See the Editors' Notes on this work.

provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Early history unknown; acquired by Alexander Macmillan by 1876; possibly by gift or bequest to a son or daughter no later than 1896 or directly to his granddaughter, Rachel M. Dyer; bequeathed by Dyer in 1969 to the National Portrait Gallery, London, and transferred in the same year to the Tate Gallery, now Tate Collection.

desc.objtitle:
Anatomical Sketch of Lower Legs,
object 1 (Butlin 127 verso)

objnote.p: This composition—evidently cut from a much larger design—appears on the verso of a piece of paper pasted to the top margin of the recto water color, An Allegory of the Bible. This strip was added to complete the recto design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this drawing, a figure's legs are shown in great anatomical detail from approximately the knee to just below the ankle. The left-leaning position of the legs suggests a figure facing forward and may stand in contrapposto or lean to the left. Alternatively, the interest paid to the underlying bone in the left leg may suggest this is an anatomical study.

component.illusobjdesc: In this drawing, a figure's legs are shown in great anatomical detail from approximately the knee to just below the ankle. The left-leaning position of the legs suggests a figure facing forward and may stand in contrapposto or lean to the left. Alternatively, the interest paid to the underlying bone in the left leg may suggest this is an anatomical study.
